The step where (e^(pi*i/2))^i became e^(pi*i^2/2) is not a valid argument. The problem is that the "identity" (a^b)^c = a^(bc), which we know for positive real a and real b and c, is not true in general for complex numbers.

As your neighberhood physicist, I have never seen a complex number to a complex number.
In all of classical physics we are dealing with observables (amplitude, magnetisation, postition, velocity) and complex exponentials arise to ease in computations (cos(x) -> e^(ix)) and as such we don't see complex bases. In this case we are mostly interested in the real part of complex numbers since these correspond to the actual observable.
In Quantum Mechanics complex numbers are much more common (due to the complex nature of the Schrödinger equation, Dirac equation, etc). But since Quantum Mechanics is equivalent to linear algebra, you still don't see complex numbers raised to complex numbers. Here we are mostly interested in the absolute value of the wave function (which is complex valued).

Finally, physics deals with observations and the real world. And we observe the universe through instruments which return real numbers. As such we are usually only interested in the real part (or absolute value) of a complex number, making detours trhough the complex world to calculate things.

But maybe quantum gravity or some weird offspring of string theory is going to change that!

A way to visualize i^i: For any 2 complex numbers z1 & z2, let z1^z2 = (Be^(iθ)) ^ (Pe^(iα)),
where length/angle of z1 (the base) is B/θ. For z2 (the power), it's P/α.
Rotate the point [ ln(B),θ ] by α. Call the result [ xα,yα ]. Then,
z1^z2 = (in polar) < e^(Pxα),Pyα >.
So i^i = <1,π/2> ^ <1,π/2>. So [ ln(B),θ ] = [ ln(1),π/2 ] =
[ 0,π/2 ]. Rotate this by α (90 deg), and you get [ xα,yα ] = [ -π/2,0 ]. So i^i = <e^(-π/2), 0>.

Okay, I'm disappointed this was never addressed - while we interpret e^x = exp(x), algebraically that is not actually true - it has the same ambiguity as any other base, and we could find other solutions to equations involving that expression. In general, if we just look at things algebraically instead of defining a specific function to satisfy the question (where we interpret a^b = exp(ln(a)*b), where ln is the principle branch of the complex logarithm), we get a^b = e^(ln(a) * b), where ln(a) is all possible solutions to the equation e^x = a. Here is the issue - if we interpret e^x to mean exp(x), then ln(a) + 2ipiZ would provide all solutions to that equation, where again ln is the principle branch of the complex algorithm. However, does this still cover all the solutions if we instead define as e^x as exp^((ln(a) + 2ipiZ) * b) instead, or have additional solutions managed to creep in? I think it's closed based on the proof that there are only so many possible exponential functions, but I don't seen it just from looking at the formula, maybe it be proven algebraically if a bit more work is done to it.

Anyway, if you define exponentiation so the output is the set of all possible solutions, and extend it to sets as the union of the output for all elements in that input set (which would be easy enough to do if exp^((ln(a) + 2ipiZ) * b) covers all possible solutions, regardless of how e^x is interpretted), then you get much different behavior for tetration. Instead of being a matter of choosing an initial interpretation, it would be the set of all branches - which would exceed the set of all solutions from all initial interpretation as branches would emerge from starting at one interpretation, but then switching to another. I saw a shitpost claiming that i^i^i^i^i is dense on the complex numbers, and if left me wondering if that is somehow true for some interpretation of exponentiation.

Even when it's to a complex number though it's still repeated multiplication -> e^2i  =  e^i * e^i. The only difference is that change what base you're multiplying by itself, but there is a geometric intuition for how you get to the changed base from the original base - you forward to get from one to the original, while you move orthogonally to get to the new changed base from raising the number to the i. Considering orthogonal rotation is what i does, I think it's an intuitive extension of iteration.

50:55 [Regarding a function f with the properties f(1)=2 and f(a + b)=f(a)f(b), which can be shown to be completely determined for all rational arguments] "...and you might wonder if that's unique, and in the context of real-valued functions it would be".

This gets super-pedantic and technical, but solutions to that functional equation are NOT unique over the reals. There's an infinite number of pathological functions that satisfy the condition on the reals. You DO get the unique solution of 2^x if you add any of the following conditions: (1) f is continuous at at least one point, (2) at some point c, there is an interval of positive length (c, d) such that f(x) > f(c) for x in (c, d), or (3) there is a set of reals of positive measure on which f is bounded either above or below.

Reference: Lectures on Functional Equations and their Applications by Aczél, sections 2.1.1 and 2.1.2

You keep saying exp is a "polynomial", but what you want to say is "power series". Non-constant polynomials have a complex root, exp doesn't have a complex root.
So basically, complex exponentials have two degrees of freedom, but the notation b^x only has one so weird overlap happens

The claim at 50:58, that a real valued such function is unique, is wrong. For this to be true you need to assume continuity. Without this, you can apply Zorn's lemma on functions on Q-subspaces of R ordered by extension to construct as many such functions as you want.

The apparent multivaluededness of i^i is still a lot weirder than those of the real examples, like 2^(1/2), 2^(1/4), because in the latter cases the reason for ambiguity is clear: only the magnitude of the answer matters while the signs or factors of i cancel out. The various values calculated for i^i however seem to have nothing obvious in common that could be used to uniquely identify the whole set of solutions with i^i; these numbers are wildly different as well as infinitely many. This is a whole new kettle of fish to x^2 = 1 <=> x = +/- 1 or even x^4 = 1 <=> x = 1, i, -1, i.

To the question if this pops up in physics, then yes.. yes it does.  This pops up in signal and frequency analysis, which you need to do with electricity in phases for example.  The last part where the solution bounces between 3 solutions is quite a normal thing to tackle, and you're looking at exactly this whole lesson when you're analysing pole-zero plots for instance.  So even though 3B1B is hammering on that this is a "generalisation", the generalisation means it's MORE applicable to models of physical phenomenons as well as a host of other things.

Okay, it seems that someone decided to call the number –2 "negative two".
Which makes some sense.
It's a negative number whose "value" is two.
Or it's the negative "version" of the number two.
So, if you are too stupid to understand that "minus" can be both a binary and a unary operator, but nevertheless clever enough to study mathematics, this notion is for you.
But you realize that "negative i" is complete nonsense, do you?
And how do you pronounce " –(–2)", by the way?

The thought of the dynamics of e^it got me thinking about acceleration. Circular motion is defined by centripetal acceleration, d^2/dt^2 r=-r, so dr/dt=±sqrt(-1)r. The two alternatives for circular motion are then r=exp(±it) corresponding to rotating in the positive or negative direction. Dope.

I think your alternative way of explaining i^i was a bit contrived. You claimed that raising e^(i*t) to i rotated a further 90 degrees the velocity, but that’s true only if you consider the initial time, t=0. What would actually rotate the dynamics is multiplying by i, so i*e^(i*t), since multiplying by i has the effect of rotating 90 degrees as you have always said. Indeed if you differentiate it, you’d get -e^(i*t) which is a 90 degree rotation from the previous tangent velocity, and that holds for any t.
Instead I felt that you tried to convey the idea that exponentiating by i has the effect of rotating by 90 degrees, which I guess confused a lot of people.

There was a question near the end about functions between addition, multiplication and exponentiation.
The best way to think of this is about growth.
Addition as described by f(x)= a+x, always grows by the same amount.
Multiplication g(x)= bx, no matter what our choices of (positive) a and b are as x gets really big our multiplication function will grow faster than our Addition formula.
Exponentiation would be h(x) = x^c, as long as c is larger than 1 this will eventually grow faster than any choice of g(x).
You are looking for a function that grows faster than any multiplication but slower than any exponent. and I can think of 1 example:
k(x)=x.log(x), will grow faster than any multiplication and slower than any exponent. it doesn't feel like a satisfying midpoint between multiplication and exponentiation though.

These videos are great, but I keep having a recurring question about the use of the Taylor polynomial and the idea that it should be introduced as the "definition" of the exponential.


Is it really "healthy" to fundamentally think of exp(x) as the infinite polynomial, when the infinite polynomial derivation requires knowledge of the derivatives of exp(x)? I understand wanting to introduce the exponential function in schools in a way that's more approachable or tangible for non integer or imaginary powers, but it's sort of circular to think of exp(x) as a power series when that power series is defined by the function itself, right?


I guess this could also be the motivation behind early vs. late transcendental curriculums

It occurs to me after watching this that raising to the i power could be a 90* rotation in another space, a transformation of the complex plane. I have not worked this all out, but here's what think it is. Take the complex plane to the Riemann sphere, take a Mercator project onto a cylinder, and unroll it to make a plane again. Think of the origin of the new plane as 1 instead of 0. I think that raising to the i power corresponds to a 90* rotation in this Mercator map.

Great video - this actually helps resolve an ambiguity I've thought about many times. What is b^x if b is negative? I.e., f(x) = (-2)^x? it's pretty easy for integer values, but as soon as you try rational values you can get different answers. For example (-2)^(3/2) can give you 2(root 2) i or  -2(root 2) i depending on if you cube it first or take the root first, so I've given up on trying to understand it. But now all you have to is define it as exp(rx) where r = ln2 + pi*I, and you'll get a unique function, or choose a different value of r, say ln2 - pi*(i) and get a different function. Both functions  spiral around the complex plane but in different directions. But now it at least makes sense to talk about exponential functions with a negative base.
